title: U.S., El Salvador Reach Deal on Asylum Seekers
text:
WASHINGTON—The Trump administration reached a deal with the government of El Salvador to send some asylum seekers from third countries back to El Salvador, in the latest effort to dissuade migrants from entering the U.S. illegally.

Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan and Salvadoran Foreign Minister Alexandra Hill signed the agreement on Friday, after days of negotiations between the two governments this week.

In a news conference following the signing, the two leaders praised one another but didn’t offer many details on the agreement.

Mr. McAleenan said that the pact will help build El Salvador’s asylum capacity—which is known to be almost nonexistent—and that the U.S. may seek to return migrants from third countries there in the future, though he didn’t elaborate on how such a system might work.

El Salvador, under pressure from the Trump administration, has already deployed 1,100 troops and immigration officers to its border with Guatemala.

It couldn’t be determined what, if anything, the Salvadoran government secured in return. The country’s popular new president, 38-year-old Nayib Bukele, has asked the Trump administration for more help to resettle deported migrants, along with more temporary U.S. worker visas for Salvadorans.

The Salvadoran government has also been pushing for the U.S. to grant permanent legal status to the 200,000 Salvadorans living in the U.S. under a program called Temporary Protected Status, which the administration has ended.

“The main issue is to protect our people that are forced to flee the country,” Ms. Hill said. “We are talking about giving them more security and increasing legal alternatives for safe migration.”

The Friday deal forms another plank of President Trump’s regional strategy to force asylum seekers to look for refuge in countries other than the U.S. The Mexican government has agreed to drastically step up border enforcement on its own southern border, contributing to a drop in border crossers coming to the U.S. in the last couple months.

As the migrant crisis on the U.S. border with Mexico intensifies, government agency leaders have been invited to testify before the House Committee on Oversight and Reform. Here's a look at the conditions drawing scrutiny and the answers lawmakers will be seeking. Photo: AFP

The deal doesn’t qualify as a safe-third-country agreement, where two countries agree that their respective counterparts are safe enough and have strong enough asylum systems so that if a migrant enters one of the countries first, they must apply for asylum in that country. Currently, the U.S. has just one safe-third-country agreement, with Canada.

In July, the Trump administration struck another safe-third-country agreement with Guatemala. The agreement has yet to be implemented.

Guatemala, like El Salvador, carries the State Department’s second-highest travel-safety warning, advising most Americans to reconsider travel there.

El Salvador’s murder rate fell by more than half between 2015 and 2018, to 50.3 homicides per 100,000 people, according to the Igarapé Institute, a think tank in Brazil that tracks global violence. That still ranks El Salvador as one of the most dangerous countries in the world, leading some refugee advocates to say it isn’t a well-suited destination for people fleeing violence.

The administration is pushing to strike similar agreements with the governments of Honduras and Panama. An agreement with Honduras could be announced within weeks, officials said.

Mr. Trump this year threatened to cut off humanitarian aid to what is known as the Northern Triangle —El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras—sparking criticism from some members of Congress who said the move would only exacerbate the crises that push migrants north. The government has since reversed some of those cuts, but the State Department has said most projects in those countries won’t be funded going forward.

President Trump said the U.S. will end Central American aid as thousands of migrants march toward the U.S. border. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains why this might be counterproductive. Photo: Getty

The administration has also made it nearly impossible for refugees to win asylum cases in the U.S. after the Supreme Court allowed it to move forward last week with a new policy disqualifying any applicants who traveled through a third country en route to the U.S. The policy still faces lower-court challenges.

El Salvador has a barely functional asylum system in place. Just 48 people have been granted asylum in the tiny Central American nation by the end of 2018, according to the United Nations refugee agency, while there were 18 pending applications.

By contrast, the U.N. agency estimates some 71,500 Salvadorans have been internally displaced by widespread violence. Around 46,800 Salvadorans sought asylum world-wide in 2018, ranking the nation sixth among countries of origin for new asylum seekers, according to the U.N.

“El Salvador has an emerging asylum system that reflects the low demand. That’s why there is no so much infrastructure right now to handle a possible higher flow,” said Giovanni Bassu, the U.N. refugee agency’s representative for Central America and Cuba. “To build [a more robust asylum system] in El Salvador won’t be easy or quick.”

—Robbie Whelan contributed to this article.

Write to Michelle Hackman at Michelle.Hackman@wsj.com and Juan Montes at juan.montes@wsj.com
